summary:
In case you missed it, we had a pretty huge presence at this year‚Äôs GitHub Universe, their global annual developer conference.  2024 was the culmination of many years of our community growing, and there were some really big moments‚Äîour community meetup in San Francisco, awards, rising in GitHub‚Äôs rankings, and being a part of the event‚Äôs Day 2 keynote.

title: Event wrap-up - GitHub Universe '24

summary:
One of the awesome people I follow on Mastodon reposted this note from another user:

People keep learning the wrong lessons from all this social media stuff.  "Clearly just move to fedi" "Bluesky is going to be totally different".  The lesson you needed to learn, which was how we used to do things in the good old internet we all pine for, is diversify your internet presence...
title: Yuck (or, why Bluesky still isn't for me)

summary: In today‚Äôs video, we‚Äôll walk through how to install the application SearXNG in a container accessible from anywhere through Tailscale.  SearXNG is a fully open-source search engine aggregator that can combine results from services and databases across the web and present them without any compromises on your privacy
title: Host your own metasearch engine to avoid tracking and profiling

summary:
I like writing Javascript without a build system
and for the millionth time yesterday I ran into a problem where I needed to
figure out how to import a Javascript library in my code without using a build
system, and it took FOREVER to figure out how to import it because the
library‚Äôs setup instructions assume that you‚Äôre using a build system. 
Luckily at this point I‚Äôve mostly learned how to navigate this situation and
either successfully use the library or decide it‚Äôs too difficult and switch to
a different library, so here‚Äôs the guide I wish I had to importing Javascript
libraries years ago. 
I‚Äôm only going to talk about using Javacript libraries on the frontend, and
only about how to use them in a no-build-system setup...
title: Importing a frontend Javascript library without a build system

summary: Life is full of little moments we love to recount later.  Here's a small collection of some of my favorites
title: The Stories We Tell

summary:
Zero-day vulnerabilities are more commonly used, according to the Five Eyes:
Key Findings
In 2023, malicious cyber actors exploited more zero-day vulnerabilities to compromise enterprise networks compared to 2022, allowing them to conduct cyber operations against higher-priority targets.  In 2023, the majority of the most frequently exploited vulnerabilities were initially exploited as a zero-day, which is an increase from 2022, when less than half of the top exploited vulnerabilities were exploited as a zero-day. 
Malicious cyber actors continue to have the most success exploiting vulnerabilities within two years after public disclosure of the vulnerability...
title: Most of 2023‚Äôs Top Exploited Vulnerabilities Were Zero-Days
